posts.title: PV Industries: Circular Solar Trial
posts.description: This project is a NSW Environment Protection Authority initiative funded from the Circular Solar Trials program.

content.introduction: This week, PV Industries announced their Circular Solar Trial. The project brings together a collaborative and industry-led approach to develop solar panel recycling and end-of-life solutions for the solar and lithium-ion battery economies. This project has been funded under the NSW Environment Protection Authority's (EPA) Circular Solar grants program.

sections.title: Project Funding
sections.content: The EPA is supporting this project through its Circular Solar Grants Program with funding of $997,969.

sections.title: Project Outcomes
sections.content: This comprehensive trial project will deliver several key outcomes:

subsections.title: Novel Recycling Process
subsections.content: Develop a novel solar panel recycling process for use in NSW by PV Industries.

subsections.title: Collection Network
subsections.content: Establish a metro and regional collection and logistics network in partnership with local government and Greentech Sydney.

subsections.title: Glass End-Markets
subsections.content: Activate end-markets for recovered solar panel glass in partnership with University of New South Wales' School of Civil and Environmental Engineering and John Holland.

subsections.title: Reuse Opportunities
subsections.content: Enable future opportunities for solar panel reuse, in partnership with UNSW's School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering.

subsections.title: Battery Safety
subsections.content: Improved procedures for safe handling and transport of lithium-ion batteries, in partnership with Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

subsections.title: Market Assessment
subsections.content: Assessment of the solar industry to identify solar panel recycling market challenges and opportunities, in partnership with University of Technology Sydney's Institute for Sustainable Futures, NSW Circular, Maoneng and Spark Renewables.

sections.title: Project Team
sections.content: PV Industries is the leading solar panel recycling and resource recovery company in Australia. They have brought together a strong project team that is uniquely placed to address challenges facing the industry, including: John Holland, the Institute for Sustainable Futures at the University of Technology Sydney, the University of New South Wales, and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).

sections.title: Project Partners
sections.content: The team is supported by a strong network of project partners including: NSW Circular, the City of Newcastle, the Hunter Joint Organisation, the Canberra Region Joint Organisation, Maoneng, Spark Renewables and Greentech Sydney.

sections.title: Project Timeline and Goals
sections.content: The project, which commenced in early 2021, will improve safe handling and transport procedures, establish a collection and logistics network for urban and regional NSW, optimise solar panel recycling and processing techniques, develop new end-markets for recovered materials and enable future market opportunities for reuse.

sections.title: CEO Statement
sections.content: "Our team is excited to be working on this important initiative which will address a rapidly growing waste issue for NSW," says Timothy Dawson, CEO of PV Industries. "We have been working closely with the solar industry for a few years now and this project will support the industry as it continues to grow."

sections.title: Project Impact
sections.content: The project will continue to increase diversion of solar panel waste from landfill, stimulate economic activity, and demonstrate the business case for a safe and sustainable circular solar and battery economy in NSW.

sections.title: Co-Founder Perspective
sections.content: "The funding has allowed us to rapidly expand our capabilities and services available to industry in NSW and Australia," says James Petesic, Co-Founder of PV Industries.

sections.title: Market Context
sections.content: Research shows solar as an area of waste is only expected to grow in the coming years, with solar panels reaching end-of-life after 10 years; 88,000 small-scale solar installations in NSW are already over 10 years old; by 2035 around 30,000 tonnes of solar panels in NSW will need to be recycled or otherwise disposed of.

sections.title: EPA Director Statement
sections.content: "The EPA's Circular Solar Grants program is directly focused on finding solutions to the emerging solar panel waste stream," said Kristie Brown, Director of Circular Economy Programs, NSW EPA. "It's a program that supports the type of trials proposed by PV Industries â€“ collaborative 'whole of supply chain' projects that provide innovative solutions to manage end-of-life solar panels and battery systems. It's all part of building the circular economy of the future in NSW."

sections.title: Industry Survey
sections.content: You can help support this project by taking part in the industry survey which will identify barriers and opportunities for a circular solar economy in NSW and Australia. The survey closed on 20 May 2022.

content.conclusion: This program was made possible thanks to funding from the NSW EPA's Circular Solar grants program: https://www.epa.nsw.gov.au/working-together/grants/infrastructure-fund/circular-solar-trials

posts.title: PV Industries: Circular Solar Phase 2
posts.description: This project is a NSW Environment Protection Authority initiative funded from the Circular Solar Phase 2 grants program

content.introduction: PV Industries proudly introduces the PV Industries: Circular Solar Phase 2. This project, part of NSW Environment Protection Authority's (EPA) Circular Solar Grants program, builds on the success of our Circular Solar Trial project. This project has been funded under the NSW Environment Protection Authority's (EPA) Circular Solar grants program.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: The EPA is supporting this project through its Circular Solar Grants Program with funding of $2,371,580. This forward-thinking initiative is poised to establish a robust circular economy for solar panels, lithium-ion batteries, and inverters in New South Wales (NSW). In alignment with circular economy principles, the project emphasises the promotion of reuse, repair, refurbishment, and sustainable end-of-life processing, diverting valuable materials away from landfills.

sections.title: Project Outcomes
sections.content: This comprehensive project will deliver several key outcomes:

subsections.title: High-Capacity Recycling Facility
subsections.content: Establish a high-capacity recycling facility in Sydney, leveraging PV Industries' innovative "De-framer" and "De-glasser" technology and include a commercial prototype for recycling the PV laminate.

subsections.title: Reverse Collection Network
subsections.content: Implement a reverse collection and logistics network to serve both metro and regional NSW that will maximise transport efficiency, divert waste from landfills, create jobs, and keep recycling efforts localised.

subsections.title: Inverter Support
subsections.content: Onshore warranty support and end-of-life processing for inverters.

subsections.title: Testing Solution Commercialisation
subsections.content: Commercialise PV Industries' solar panel testing solution allowing solar panel installers to test solar panels in position without individual removal, optimising performance and generating instant reports for clients.

subsections.title: Glass End-Markets
subsections.content: Develop end-markets for recovered solar panel glass particularly in high-value construction applications.

sections.title: Background Information
sections.content: PV Industries, the leading solar panel recycling and resource recovery company in Australia, has assembled a robust project team to tackle industry challenges. This team is supported by a strong network of partners including the University of New South Wales (UNSW).

sections.title: Project Impact
sections.content: The PV Industries: Circular Solar Phase 2 project is a testament to PV Industries' commitment to innovation, sustainability, and responsible resource management. This pioneering effort is set to elevate NSW's position in the circular economy landscape, creating a shift in how we approach and manage end-of-life solar technologies.

sections.title: Leadership Vision
sections.content: Timothy Dawson, CEO of PV Industries, expressed excitement about addressing the growing waste issue in NSW, emphasising the project's support for the expanding solar industry. The ongoing initiative will further divert solar panel waste from landfills, boost economic activity, and showcase the business case for a safe and sustainable circular solar and battery economy in NSW.

sections.title: CEO Statement
sections.content: "The ongoing support from the NSW EPA has provided PV Industries with a strong foundation to deliver viable recycling solutions and be market leaders both domestically and internationally," says Timothy Dawson. "The Phase 2 grant funding has allowed PV Industries to consolidate its findings from the Circular Solar Trial and begin to scale up our solutions for the circular solar economy."

sections.title: Industry Collaboration
sections.content: If you are part of the solar industry and you would like to learn how you can help support this important project you can contact the project team at https://www.pvindustries.com.au/contact/ or contact us using the button below.

content.conclusion: This program was made possible thanks to funding from the NSW EPA's Circular Solar grants program: https://www.epa.nsw.gov.au/working-together/grants/infrastructure-fund/circular-solar-trials

posts.title: PV Industries receives funding from Sustainability Victoria
posts.description: PV Industries has been awarded $400,000 through the Victorian Government's Circular Economy Markets Fund

content.introduction: PV Industries has been awarded $400,000 through the Victorian Government's Circular Economy Markets Fund for our project "Validating a new commercial pathway for solar panel glass".

sections.title: Project Outcome
sections.content: The outcome of this project is to have a confirmed solar panel recycling plant design configuration that produces a glass product suitable and validated for commercial use in Victorian end-market applications. This will be done by establishing a commercial pilot plant which demonstrates a process to recover the glass from solar panels.

sections.title: Circular Economy Investment
sections.content: The circular economy policy is part of the Victorian Government's $515 million investment to deliver the biggest ever transformation of Victoria's waste and recycling industry.

sections.title: Additional Information
sections.content: More information on the Circular Economy Markets Fund: Materials can be found at Stream 1 research, development and demonstration programs. More information on the project can be found on our dedicated project page.

content.conclusion: This funding represents a significant milestone in establishing commercial pathways for solar panel glass recovery in Victoria, supporting the state's transition to a circular economy.

posts.title: UTS Study to enable Circular Solar Economy
posts.description: As many of Australia's rooftop solar PV systems near the end of their life, it is crucial to develop strategic circular economy strategies.

content.introduction: In the evolving landscape of renewable energy, the Institute for Sustainable Futures (ISF) spearheads a groundbreaking initiative to propel the transition to a circular economy for solar panels and energy storage batteries. This work forms part of our project, PV Industries: Circular Solar Trial, funded by the NSW Environment Protection Authority.

sections.title: The Challenge Ahead
sections.content: As Australia faces the impending end-of-life phase for a considerable number of rooftop solar PV systems, the need for strategic circular economy strategies becomes paramount. Without proper measures, waste volumes from retired solar PV systems could surge to alarming levels by 2040. The potential waste crisis necessitates urgent adoption of circular economy practices to reuse and recycle panels and components, mitigating environmental impacts and steering Australia towards a sustainable future.

sections.title: Government Investment for Change
sections.content: Recognizing the urgency, the NSW Government has committed a $10 million fund to facilitate the state's transition to a circular economy for renewable energy sources. This financial support underscores the commitment to building sustainable supply chains and reducing the ecological footprint associated with the renewable energy sector.

sections.title: Research Insights
sections.content: As part of a comprehensive project led by PV Industries and funded by the NSW Environment Protection Authority, ISF conducted groundbreaking research with three key outputs:

subsections.title: Material Flow Analysis
subsections.content: An up-to-date material flow and spatial model to estimate resource recovery potential in Australia.

subsections.title: Industry Survey
subsections.content: A comprehensive survey of approximately 50 installers to understand decommissioning and end-of-life management practices.

subsections.title: Expert Interviews
subsections.content: Interviews with industry, policy, and academic experts to evaluate reuse market opportunities and identify barriers and enablers.

sections.title: The Path to Circular Economy
sections.content: Establishing a circular economy for PV systems involves transformative changes across the supply chain. This includes promoting circular design and manufacturing, maximizing product lifetimes through maintenance and repair, instituting high-value recycling, and minimizing landfilling.

sections.title: Opportunities and Challenges
sections.content: The research underscores the significant opportunity for PV system reuse in Australia. However, challenges lie in an under-developed domestic second-hand market and an unregulated export market to low- and middle-income regions. This poses a risk of exporting a waste problem if destination countries lack the infrastructure to manage these products at the end of their lifecycle.

sections.title: Enabling Reuse Pathways
sections.content: To unlock the potential of reuse pathways, the research emphasizes the need to:

subsections.title: Standards Development
subsections.content: Establish definitions and criteria for reusability, and develop new standards for repairing and testing second-hand systems.

subsections.title: Customer Assurance
subsections.content: Provide information and assurances for customers purchasing second-hand systems.

subsections.title: Logistics Solutions
subsections.content: Ensure emerging reverse logistics solutions are designed to facilitate reuse.

subsections.title: Financial Incentives
subsections.content: Develop new financial incentives for repaired and tested systems to be cost-competitive.

content.conclusion: As we stand at the forefront of sustainable energy practices, embracing circular economy principles for PV systems is not just a choice; it is a necessity. Through collaborative efforts, informed policymaking, and strategic investments, we can usher in a future where renewable energy technologies contribute to a circular and sustainable economy. The journey has begun, and the destination promises a cleaner, greener, and more resilient tomorrow.

posts.title: Newcastle Drop-Off Point Open
posts.description: A state-of-the-art drop-off point for end-of-life solar panels at the Summerhill Waste Management Centre.

content.introduction: In a significant leap towards fostering environmental responsibility, the City of Newcastle proudly introduces a state-of-the-art drop-off point for end-of-life solar panels at the Summerhill Waste Management Centre. Now open to the public, this initiative is poised to provide access to the Newcastle and Hunter region to this new service.

sections.title: The Need for Responsible Solar Panel Disposal
sections.content: As the number of solar panel installations rises, so does the importance of responsible disposal practices. End-of-life solar panels can pose environmental challenges if not handled properly. Recognizing this, the City of Newcastle is taking proactive steps to ensure the responsible disposal and recycling of these panels through the new drop-off point at Summerhill.

sections.title: Key Features of the Drop-Off Point
sections.content: The new facility offers several important features:

subsections.title: Convenient Location
subsections.content: The drop-off point is strategically located at the Summerhill Waste Management Centre, providing easy access for residents and businesses in Newcastle.

subsections.title: Open to the Public
subsections.content: This facility is open to the public, allowing individuals and organizations to contribute to sustainable waste management practices.

subsections.title: Expert Recycling Processes
subsections.content: The Summerhill Waste Management Centre has partnered with PV Industries with advanced recycling processes specifically designed for solar panels. This ensures that materials are efficiently separated and recycled in an environmentally friendly manner.

sections.title: How to Utilize the Drop-Off Point
sections.content: Using the new drop-off point is straightforward:

subsections.title: Prepare Panels for Drop-Off
subsections.content: Ensure panels are safely disconnected and prepared for drop-off. If you have any questions about preparation, feel free to reach out to PV Industries or the waste management centre for guidance.

subsections.title: Visit Summerhill Waste Management Centre
subsections.content: Bring your end-of-life solar panels to the Summerhill Waste Management Centre during operating hours.

subsections.title: Contribute to Sustainability
subsections.content: By utilizing this drop-off point, you play a crucial role in supporting Newcastle's commitment to sustainability and responsible waste management.

sections.title: The City of Newcastle's Commitment
sections.content: This initiative is a testament to the City of Newcastle's commitment to environmental stewardship and the circular economy. By establishing a dedicated drop-off point for end-of-life solar panels, the city aims to minimize waste, promote recycling, and create a more sustainable community.

content.conclusion: The opening of Newcastle's solar panel drop-off point represents a significant step forward in regional waste management and environmental responsibility, providing the Hunter region with accessible recycling solutions for end-of-life solar panels.

posts.title: Solar Panel Recycling: A Business Opportunity for Cost Savings and Resource Recovery
posts.description: As the global solar energy market grows, the need for efficient end-of-life management becomes critical. Discover how recycling solar panels offers businesses opportunities for cost reduction, resource recovery, and long-term profitability.

content.introduction: As the global solar energy market grows, the need for efficient end-of-life (EoL) management becomes critical. Recycling solar panels not only supports environmental sustainability but also offers businesses opportunities for cost reduction, resource recovery, and long-term profitability.

sections.title: Market Growth and Solar Waste
sections.content: With millions of solar panels reaching the end of their life in the coming decades, the industry requires urgent recycling solutions. Globally, a projected 60 million metric tons of global solar panel waste will be produced by 2050, with Australia potentially contributing 3 million tons to that figure. Proper recycling can reduce costs, provide valuable materials, and support a circular economy.

sections.title: Material Recovery
sections.content: Solar panels contain valuable materials like silicon, silver, aluminum, and glass, which can be recycled to reduce reliance on costly, energy-intensive virgin material extraction and production.

subsections.title: Silicon
subsections.content: Energy-efficient, lower-cost alternative to mining.

subsections.title: Silver
subsections.content: Recoverable valuable commodity.

subsections.title: Aluminium & Glass
subsections.content: Easily recyclable, reducing energy costs and environmental impact.

sections.title: Cost Reduction and Operational Efficiencies
sections.content: Recycling reduces the need for virgin materials, stabilises prices, lowers manufacturing costs, and saves energy, benefiting both manufacturers and the environment. By using recycled materials instead of relying solely on virgin materials, the supply of materials becomes more consistent, which helps prevent significant price fluctuation caused by changes in supply and demand for virgin materials.

sections.title: Circular Economy
sections.content: The metals and glass contained in a solar panel are able to be recycled an infinite number of times when cleanly separated. Recycling promotes sustainability by closing the loop on material use, reducing waste, reducing our reliance on virgin materials, ensuring long-term cost savings and regulatory compliance.

sections.title: Job Creation and Economic Growth
sections.content: Establishing recycling infrastructure creates jobs in engineering, logistics, and manufacturing. Local facilities can stimulate regional economies and reduce transportation costs. In 2024, the Australian Council of Recycling have reported that one job is supported for every 430 tonnes of material recycled in Australia. Solar Panel waste is projected to be the largest waste stream facing Australia in the next 20 years (by weight) and hence, presents the largest opportunity for job creation if tackled correctly.

sections.title: Market Differentiation and Consumer Demand
sections.content: Sustainable business practices attract environmentally-conscious consumers and investors, offering a competitive edge in an increasingly green-focused market.

sections.title: Risk Mitigation and Compliance
sections.content: Investing in recycling strategies ensures compliance with growing waste management regulations, reducing legal and reputational risks. Additionally, adopting solar panel recycling practices aligns with Environmental, Social, and Governance targets to improve sustainability, ethical practices, and corporate responsibility and CSR goals, demonstrating a company's commitment to environmental responsibility, social value creation, and ethical governance, which can further enhance brand reputation and stakeholder trust.

content.conclusion: In summary, partnering with a reputable solar panel recycler presents a key opportunity for businesses to strengthen brand reputation, recover valuable materials, support job creation, and contribute to a sustainable circular economy. Early investment in recycling technology and EOL management will position companies for long-term growth in an expanding, environmentally-driven market.

posts.title: CRC-P: Machine Learning Driven Large-Scale Solar Panel Recycling Process
posts.description: This project lays the groundwork for robust solutions to address the substantial volumes of future PV waste.

content.introduction: In January 2024, PV Industries proudly received the Cooperative Research Centres Projects (CRC-P) Grant, marking a significant milestone for our business. With a duration of three years and $3 million in funding from the Federal Government, this initiative exemplifies forward-thinking and innovation.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project lays the groundwork for robust solutions to address the substantial volumes of future PV waste. By focusing on enhancing process capacity and implementing machine learning technologies, we aim to drive increased efficiencies in our operations.

sections.title: Project Outcomes
sections.content: The CRC-P grant will enable us to achieve several key outcomes that will transform the solar panel recycling industry:

subsections.title: Advanced Testing Solutions
subsections.content: Advance development of PV Industries' solar panel testing solution allowing solar panel installers to test solar panels in position without individual removal, optimising performance and generating instant reports for clients.

subsections.title: High-Capacity Recycling Facility
subsections.content: Establish a high-capacity solar panel recycling facility designed specifically to handle the decommissioning of solar farms.

subsections.title: End-Market Development
subsections.content: Develop end-markets for recovered solar panel glass particularly in high-value construction applications.

sections.title: Background Information
sections.content: Australia has installed over 100 million solar panels, boasting the highest per-capita penetration in the world. However, the surge of solar panel e-waste presents a challenge, as their stated 25-year lifespan can be shortened by various faults and defects that are hard and costly to detect manually. Globally, there is no efficient recycling solution to accommodate the exponential growth in solar panel waste, and higher value end-markets for materials remain undeveloped.

sections.title: Collaborative Approach
sections.content: PV Industries, in collaboration with ReSource, UNSW, and Spark Renewables, is pioneering a large-scale, high-volume solar panel testing and recycling process from decommissioning to end-markets, utilising machine learning to optimise both environmental and economic outcomes.

content.conclusion: "This CRC-P funding will see PV Industries deliver the largest bespoke solar panel recycling facility in Australia" says Troy Rowe, PV Industries Director. Information regarding all successful round 15 CRC-P projects can be found here: https://business.gov.au/grants-and-programs/cooperative-research-centres-projects-crcp-grants/crc-projects-selection-round-outcomes

posts.title: Recycling Solar Panels: Chipping Away at our Mountain of Waste
posts.description: Keep Australia Beautiful recently engaged with PV Industries to gain insights into the Australian solar panel recycling sector

content.introduction: Keep Australia Beautiful, a non-profit organization dedicated to fostering community awareness and education for environmental preservation, recently engaged with PV Industries to gain insights into the Australian solar panel recycling sector.

sections.title: The Discussion
sections.content: James Petesic met with Laura Carrazza, discussing topics such as the projected increase in end-of-life solar panels over the coming years, the current state of the solar recycling industry, the recyclable materials and their environmental benefits, concerns regarding offshore exportation of panels to Africa and the Middle East, and the Australian Government's strategies to bolster the solar recycling sector.

sections.title: The Importance of Public Awareness
sections.content: Initiatives like Keep Australia Beautiful play a pivotal role in advancing public awareness regarding waste management practices. It was a privilege to shed light on the significance of solar recycling, especially considering our reliance on renewable energy to achieve national carbon reduction goals.

sections.title: Sustainability of Renewable Energy
sections.content: In essence, without proper recycling, the sustainability of renewable energy is compromised. This highlights the critical importance of developing comprehensive end-of-life solutions for solar panels as we continue to expand renewable energy infrastructure across Australia.

content.conclusion: For more information about this discussion and Keep Australia Beautiful's work in environmental preservation, visit: https://kab.org.au/recycling-solar-panels-chipping-away-at-our-mountain-of-waste/

posts.title: Podcast Feature: Executive With A Cause
posts.description: In this episode of Executive with a Cause, host Tammy Ven Dange chats with James Petesic, Co-Founder of PV Industries.

content.introduction: In this episode of Executive with a Cause, host Tammy Ven Dange chats with James Petesic, Co-Founder of PV Industries.

sections.title: Maintaining Vision While Ensuring Financial Viability
sections.content: How does a young company maintain vision whilst ensuring financial viability? And how can the lifecycle of solar panels be better managed and tracked? In this episode, we hear from Co-Founder James Petesic on how he maintained the foundational values of his social enterprise whilst growing solar panel recycling venture PV Industries.

sections.title: Impact Investment and Values-Based Growth
sections.content: Impact investment requires a different mindset to traditional Return on Investment focused funding relationships. On this, James explains how PV Industries have balanced attracting investors whilst serving the company's values and sticking to a niche market. Furthermore, we hear how they have demonstrated 'trusting the process', and waiting for the right opportunity rather than premature growth.

sections.title: Solar Panel Lifecycle Tracking
sections.content: We also learn about tracking the lifecycle of solar panels, and the opportunity to improve this process in Australia. This represents a significant opportunity for better waste management and resource recovery in the renewable energy sector.

sections.title: Future Plans and Scale
sections.content: Finally, James explains their future plans and desire to increase their scale and revenue from material recycling, as well as improve the reputation of waste management. This includes expanding operations and developing new technologies for more efficient recycling processes.

content.conclusion: To listen to this podcast episode, visit: https://roundboxconsulting.com.au/2022/10/31/james-petesic/
